resources.string: The Sun is the star at the center of our solar system. It provides the light and heat that makes life on Earth possible.
The Sun contains 99.86% of all mass in our solar system. About 1.3 million Earths could fit inside it!
The Moon is Earth\'s only natural satellite. It influences our tides and has been visited by 12 astronauts.
The Moon is slowly drifting away from Earth at about 3.8 cm per year. It was much closer billions of years ago!
Mercury is the smallest planet and closest to the Sun. A year on Mercury lasts only 88 Earth days.
Despite being closest to the Sun, Mercury is not the hottest planet. Venus is hotter due to its thick atmosphere!
Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the hottest in our solar system. It\'s often called Earth\'s twin due to similar size.
A day on Venus is longer than its year! It takes 243 Earth days to rotate once, but only 225 days to orbit the Sun.
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide on its surface.
Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system: Olympus Mons, which is about 2.5 times taller than Mount Everest!
Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system. It\'s a gas giant with a famous Great Red Spot storm.
Jupiter has at least 95 known moons! Its largest moon, Ganymede, is bigger than the planet Mercury.
Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its spectacular ring system made of ice and rock.
Saturn is so light it would float in water! Its density is less than water, though there\'s no bathtub big enough to test this.
Uranus is an ice giant that rotates on its side. It was the first planet discovered using a telescope.
Uranus rotates on its side at a 98-degree tilt, possibly due to a collision with an Earth-sized object long ago!
Neptune is the most distant planet in our solar system. It has the strongest winds, reaching 2,100 km/h.
Neptune was discovered through mathematics! Scientists predicted its location before anyone saw it through a telescope.
Pluto is a dwarf planet in the Kuiper Belt. It was considered the ninth planet until 2006.
Pluto has a heart-shaped glacier made of nitrogen ice, visible in images from NASA\'s New Horizons mission!
Sirius is the brightest star in the night sky, located in the constellation Canis Major (the Greater Dog).
Sirius is actually a binary star system! Sirius B, its companion, is a white dwarf about the size of Earth but nearly as massive as the Sun.
Vega is one of the brightest stars visible from Earth, located in the constellation Lyra (the Harp).
Vega was the North Star about 14,000 years ago and will be again in about 12,000 years due to Earth\'s wobble!
Betelgeuse is a red supergiant star marking the shoulder of Orion. It\'s one of the largest stars visible to the naked eye.
Betelgeuse is so large that if placed at our Sun\'s position, it would engulf Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, and possibly Jupiter!
Rigel is a blue supergiant star marking the foot of Orion. Despite being farther than Betelgeuse, it appears similarly bright.
Rigel shines with the light of about 120,000 Suns! It\'s one of the most luminous stars in our region of the Milky Way.
Procyon is a bright star in the constellation Canis Minor (the Lesser Dog). It\'s one of our closer stellar neighbors.
Procyon means \"before the dog\" in Greek because it rises just before Sirius, the Dog Star, in the night sky!
Polaris, the North Star, appears nearly motionless in the sky while other stars rotate around it throughout the night.
Polaris is actually a triple star system! The main star is a supergiant about 2,500 times brighter than our Sun.
Deneb marks the tail of Cygnus (the Swan). It\'s part of the Summer Triangle asterism along with Vega and Altair.
Deneb is one of the most distant stars visible to the naked eye, located about 2,600 light-years away!
Arcturus is the brightest star in the northern hemisphere, an orange giant in the constellation Boötes (the Herdsman).
Arcturus is traveling through space at a tremendous speed and will pass closest to our solar system in about 4,000 years!
Canopus is the second-brightest star in the night sky. It\'s visible mainly from the Southern Hemisphere.
Canopus is used by spacecraft for navigation because it\'s very bright and far from the ecliptic plane!
Aldebaran is an orange giant star that represents the eye of Taurus (the Bull). Its name means \"the follower\" in Arabic.
Aldebaran appears to be part of the Hyades star cluster but is actually only half the distance to us - a cosmic optical illusion!
Antares is a red supergiant star, the heart of Scorpius (the Scorpion). Its name means \"rival of Mars\" due to its red color.
Antares is so large that if placed in our solar system, its surface would extend past the orbit of Mars!
Capella is the brightest star in Auriga and the sixth-brightest in the night sky. It\'s actually a system of four stars.
Capella means \"little goat\" in Latin. Ancient cultures saw it as a goat carried on the shoulder of Auriga, the Charioteer!
Altair is the brightest star in Aquila (the Eagle) and one of the closest stars visible to the naked eye.
Altair rotates so fast (once every 9 hours) that it\'s noticeably flattened at its poles - it\'s 14% wider than it is tall!
Spica is the brightest star in Virgo and one of the 20 brightest stars in the night sky. It\'s a binary star system.
Spica is so close to the ecliptic that it can be occulted by the Moon. The name means \"ear of wheat\" in Latin!
Achernar is the brightest star in Eridanus (the River) and the ninth-brightest star in the night sky.
Achernar is the flattest star known! It spins so fast that its equatorial diameter is 56% larger than its polar diameter.
Hadar (Beta Centauri) is the second-brightest star in Centaurus and the 11th brightest in the night sky.
Hadar and Alpha Centauri are known as the \"Southern Pointers\" - they point to the Southern Cross constellation!
Regulus is the brightest star in Leo (the Lion) and represents the lion\'s heart. It\'s a multiple star system.
Regulus spins so fast it\'s nearly tearing itself apart! It completes a rotation in just 16 hours.
Acrux (Alpha Crucis) is the brightest star in the Southern Cross and the 13th brightest star in the sky.
Acrux appears on the flags of Australia, New Zealand, Brazil, Papua New Guinea, and Samoa!
Castor is one of the twin stars in Gemini. Though it appears as one star, it\'s actually a system of six stars!
Castor is a sextuple star system - three pairs of binary stars all orbiting each other. It\'s one of the most complex star systems near Earth!
Pollux is the brighter of the twin stars in Gemini. Unlike Castor, it\'s a single orange giant star.
Pollux has a confirmed exoplanet! Pollux b is a gas giant at least twice as massive as Jupiter.
Fomalhaut is the brightest star in Piscis Austrinus and one of the brightest stars in the autumn sky.
Fomalhaut has a spectacular debris disk that was one of the first to be directly imaged around another star!
Adhara (Epsilon Canis Majoris) is the second-brightest star in Canis Major, after Sirius.
About 4.7 million years ago, Adhara was the brightest star in the night sky, even brighter than Sirius is today!
Shaula is the second-brightest star in Scorpius and marks the scorpion\'s stinger in the tail.
Shaula means \"the raised tail\" in Arabic. It\'s actually a triple star system with the stars very close together!
Alnilam is the middle star of Orion\'s Belt and one of the most luminous stars known in our galaxy.
Alnilam is losing mass at a rate of 20 million times faster than our Sun through its powerful stellar wind!
Alphard is the brightest star in Hydra (the Water Snake), the largest constellation in the sky.
Alphard means \"the solitary one\" in Arabic because it sits alone in an otherwise dim region of sky!
Mirach is a red giant star in Andromeda, often used as a guide to find the Andromeda Galaxy.
Mirach\'s Ghost is a small galaxy (NGC 404) that appears very close to Mirach - it was hidden by the star\'s glare for centuries!
Algol is a famous eclipsing binary star in Perseus, known as the \"Demon Star\" since ancient times.
Every 2.87 days, Algol dims noticeably as its dimmer companion passes in front - ancient astronomers found this spooky!
Alpha Centauri is the closest star system to the Sun, consisting of three stars including Proxima Centauri.
Proxima Centauri, part of this system, has a potentially habitable planet! Proxima b is only 4.2 light-years away.
Dubhe is one of the two \"pointer stars\" in the Big Dipper that point to Polaris, the North Star.
Unlike most Big Dipper stars, Dubhe and Alkaid are moving in the opposite direction - the asterism will look different in 50,000 years!
Alioth is the brightest star in Ursa Major and the brightest star in the Big Dipper asterism.
Alioth has a peculiar magnetic field that causes chemical elements to concentrate in spots on its surface!
Hamal is the brightest star in Aries and was once used to mark the vernal equinox about 2,000 years ago.
A giant exoplanet was discovered orbiting Hamal in 2011, at least 1.8 times Jupiter\'s mass!
Rasalhague is the brightest star in Ophiuchus (the Serpent-Bearer), a constellation associated with healing.
Rasalhague is a rapid rotator - it spins so fast that it\'s noticeably flattened, completing a rotation in just 18 hours!
Denebola marks the tail of Leo (the Lion). Its name literally means \"tail of the lion\" in Arabic.
Denebola has a dusty debris disk that may indicate planets are forming or asteroids are colliding around it!
Alpheratz is the brightest star in Andromeda, though it was once considered part of Pegasus.
Alpheratz has an extremely unusual chemical composition with high concentrations of mercury and manganese in its atmosphere!
Markab is one of the four stars forming the Great Square of Pegasus, an easily recognizable asterism.
Markab is a \"late B-type\" star that\'s just finishing its main sequence life and will soon become a red giant!
Enif is the brightest star in Pegasus and marks the nose of the flying horse in the constellation.
In 1972, Enif experienced a dramatic flare event, briefly increasing its brightness by a factor of five!
Scheat is a red giant star in the Great Square of Pegasus, notable for its deep orange-red color.
Scheat is a semi-regular variable star, changing brightness over periods ranging from weeks to months!
Nunki is the second-brightest star in Sagittarius and the oldest star name still in common use.
The name Nunki comes from ancient Babylon where it represented the city of Eridu on the celestial sphere!
Diphda (Beta Ceti) is the brightest star in Cetus (the Sea Monster) and a prominent autumn star.
Diphda appears isolated in a rather barren region of sky, making it useful for navigators despite not being extremely bright!
The Crab Nebula is a supernova remnant in Taurus, the result of a stellar explosion recorded by Chinese astronomers in 1054 AD.
The Crab Nebula contains a pulsar spinning 30 times per second, the collapsed core of the exploded star!
M13 is a spectacular globular cluster in Hercules containing about 300,000 stars, one of the brightest in the northern sky.
In 1974, the Arecibo message was beamed toward M13 as an attempt to contact extraterrestrial intelligence!
The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest large spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and one of the most distant objects visible to the naked eye.
The Andromeda Galaxy is approaching us at 110 km/s and will collide with the Milky Way in about 4.5 billion years!
The Orion Nebula is a diffuse emission nebula visible to the naked eye, one of the most photographed objects in the night sky.
The Orion Nebula is a stellar nursery where new stars are being born right now. Over 700 stars are forming inside!
The Pleiades is an open star cluster in Taurus, also known as the Seven Sisters, visible to the naked eye since antiquity.
The Pleiades are among the nearest star clusters to Earth and have been recognized by virtually every ancient civilization!
The Whirlpool Galaxy is a grand-design spiral galaxy in Canes Venatici, famous for its striking spiral arms and companion galaxy.
The Whirlpool was the first galaxy to be recognized as having spiral structure, discovered by Lord Rosse in 1845!
The Ring Nebula is a planetary nebula in Lyra, a glowing shell of gas expelled by a dying Sun-like star.
The Ring Nebula is expanding at about 20 km/s and will eventually disperse into space over the next 10,000 years!
M81 is a grand-design spiral galaxy in Ursa Major, one of the brightest galaxies visible from Earth.
M81 is gravitationally interacting with neighboring galaxy M82, triggering intense star formation in M82!
The Cigar Galaxy is a starburst galaxy in Ursa Major, known for its edge-on orientation and intense star formation.
M82 is forming stars 10 times faster than our Milky Way due to gravitational interaction with neighboring M81!
The Pinwheel Galaxy is a face-on spiral galaxy in Ursa Major, one of the largest known spiral galaxies.
The Pinwheel Galaxy contains over a trillion stars and has asymmetric spiral arms due to past galaxy interactions!
The Sombrero Galaxy is a spiral galaxy in Virgo, famous for its bright nucleus and large central bulge with a dark dust lane.
The Sombrero Galaxy has a supermassive black hole at its center estimated to be 1 billion solar masses!
The Lagoon Nebula is a giant interstellar cloud in Sagittarius, one of the finest and brightest nebulae in the summer sky.
The Lagoon Nebula contains Herschel 36, one of the most massive and luminous stars known!
The Omega Nebula (also Swan Nebula) is a star-forming region in Sagittarius, one of the brightest emission nebulae.
The Omega Nebula contains an open cluster of about 800 young stars hidden within its gas and dust!
The Trifid Nebula is a combination of emission, reflection, and dark nebulae in Sagittarius, divided by dark dust lanes.
The Trifid shows three distinct types of nebulae in one object: red emission, blue reflection, and dark absorption!
The Dumbbell Nebula is a planetary nebula in Vulpecula, the first planetary nebula ever discovered.
The Dumbbell Nebula was discovered by Charles Messier in 1764, making it the first planetary nebula ever discovered!
The Triangulum Galaxy is the third-largest member of the Local Group, a spiral galaxy visible in Triangulum constellation.
The Triangulum Galaxy may be gravitationally bound to the Andromeda Galaxy as a distant satellite!
M35 is a large open star cluster in Gemini, visible to the naked eye under good conditions.
M35 contains about 200 stars and appears near a much older cluster NGC 2158 in the same field of view!
The Beehive Cluster (Praesepe) is an open cluster in Cancer, known since ancient times and visible to the naked eye.
Ancient astronomers used the visibility of the Beehive Cluster to predict weather - if invisible, rain was coming!
M78 is the brightest diffuse reflection nebula in the sky, located in Orion near the famous Belt stars.
M78 contains about 45 young T Tauri variable stars, very young stars still contracting toward the main sequence!
The Southern Pinwheel is a barred spiral galaxy in Hydra, one of the closest and brightest barred spirals in our sky.
M83 has produced six observed supernovae, more than any other galaxy - a record for supernova production!
M3 is one of the largest and brightest globular clusters in the sky, located in Canes Venatici.
M3 contains about 500,000 stars and is estimated to be 11.4 billion years old!
M5 is a globular cluster in Serpens, one of the oldest globular clusters at about 13 billion years old.
M5 contains over 100,000 stars and has one of the highest numbers of known variable stars of any globular cluster!
M15 is a dense globular cluster in Pegasus, notable for having a planetary nebula at its core - very rare for globular clusters.
M15 may contain a central black hole of about 4,000 solar masses, though this is still debated!
M22 is one of the nearest and brightest globular clusters to Earth, located in Sagittarius near the galactic center.
M22 was one of the first globular clusters discovered, found by Abraham Ihle in 1665!
M4 is one of the closest globular clusters to Earth and one of the easiest to find, located near Antares in Scorpius.
M4 contains a white dwarf estimated to be 13 billion years old - one of the oldest known stars in the Milky Way!
The Ptolemy Cluster is a bright open cluster in Scorpius, one of the most prominent clusters visible to the naked eye.
M7 was first recorded by Ptolemy in 130 AD and has been observed for nearly 2,000 years!
The Butterfly Cluster is an open cluster in Scorpius, named for the butterfly-like arrangement of its brightest stars.
M6 is about 100 million years old and contains over 300 stars, including the orange giant BM Scorpii!
The Wild Duck Cluster is a rich open cluster in Scutum, one of the most compact open clusters known.
M11 contains nearly 3,000 stars packed into a small area, creating a spectacular view through telescopes!
The Eagle Nebula is a star-forming nebula in Serpens, famous for the Pillars of Creation imaged by Hubble.
The Pillars of Creation in M16 are about 5 light-years tall and are being slowly eroded by radiation from nearby stars!
M2 is one of the largest and richest globular clusters known, located in Aquarius.
M2 contains about 150,000 stars and has a diameter of 175 light-years, making it one of the largest globulars!
M10 is a bright globular cluster in Ophiuchus, one of the closer globular clusters to our solar system.
M10 is approaching us at over 70 km/s and has an unusually low concentration of stars at its core!
M12 is a globular cluster in Ophiuchus, notable for its relatively loose central concentration.
M12 has lost many of its low-mass stars due to the gravitational pull of the Milky Way over billions of years!
M14 is a globular cluster in Ophiuchus containing several hundred thousand stars.
In 1938, a nova appeared in M14 but was not discovered until 1964 when old photographic plates were examined!
M53 is a globular cluster in Coma Berenices, one of the more outlying globular clusters in our galaxy.
M53 is one of the most distant globular clusters from the galactic center at 60,000 light-years away from it!
The Black Eye Galaxy is a spiral galaxy in Coma Berenices, famous for the dark band of absorbing dust around its nucleus.
The outer regions of M64 rotate in the opposite direction from its inner regions, likely from a past galaxy merger!
M65 is a spiral galaxy in Leo, part of the famous Leo Triplet along with M66 and NGC 3628.
The Leo Triplet galaxies are gravitationally interacting, causing tidal tails and warped structures!
M66 is the largest member of the Leo Triplet, a spiral galaxy with asymmetric spiral arms.
M66\'s asymmetric appearance is caused by gravitational interactions with its neighbors M65 and NGC 3628!
The Phantom Galaxy is a face-on spiral galaxy in Pisces, known for its perfect grand-design spiral structure.
M74 is nicknamed the Phantom Galaxy because of its very low surface brightness, making it challenging to observe!
M77 is a barred spiral galaxy in Cetus containing an active galactic nucleus powered by a supermassive black hole.
M77 harbors an active galactic nucleus with a black hole 15 million times the mass of our Sun!
M92 is a bright globular cluster in Hercules, often overlooked because of its proximity to the more famous M13.
M92 is one of the oldest globular clusters at about 14.2 billion years old - nearly as old as the universe!
M94 is a spiral galaxy in Canes Venatici with a bright inner ring where active star formation is occurring.
M94\'s inner ring is a starburst ring where new stars are forming at a very high rate!
The Owl Nebula is a planetary nebula in Ursa Major, named for its owl-like appearance with two dark spots.
The dark owl eyes in M97 are three-dimensional cavities in the nebula, aligned with our line of sight!
M106 is a spiral galaxy in Canes Venatici with anomalous spiral arms caused by jets from its central black hole.
M106 has water masers in its nucleus, allowing astronomers to precisely measure its distance!
M109 is a barred spiral galaxy in Ursa Major, the brightest member of a galaxy group bearing its name.
M109 is located very close to the star Phecda in the Big Dipper, making it easy to locate!
M110 is a dwarf elliptical galaxy and satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy, the last object added to the Messier catalog.
M110 was actually observed by Messier in 1773 but not added to his catalog until 1966!
M32 is a compact dwarf elliptical galaxy and close satellite of the Andromeda Galaxy.
M32 was the first elliptical galaxy ever discovered and may have once been a larger spiral galaxy stripped by Andromeda!
M49 is a giant elliptical galaxy in Virgo, the brightest member of the Virgo Cluster.
M49 was the first member of the Virgo Cluster to be discovered and contains about 6,000 globular clusters!
M87 is a supergiant elliptical galaxy in Virgo, one of the most massive galaxies in the local universe.
M87\'s central black hole was the first ever imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope in 2019 - it has 6.5 billion solar masses!

T Coronae Borealis (T CrB) is a recurrent nova in Corona Borealis — a binary system of a red giant and a white dwarf. The white dwarf periodically accumulates enough hydrogen from its companion to trigger a thermonuclear explosion.
T CrB last erupted in 1946, briefly reaching magnitude 2.0 and becoming visible to the naked eye. Astronomers predict that another eruption is imminent — keep watching!

The Eta Carinae Nebula (NGC 3372) is one of the largest and brightest nebulae in the sky, spanning over 300 light-years. At its heart sits Eta Carinae, one of the most massive and luminous stars known, weighing over 100 solar masses.
In 1843 Eta Carinae erupted and briefly became the second-brightest star in the sky, yet somehow it survived — it may be on the verge of going supernova!
Orion the Hunter is one of the most recognizable constellations, visible from both hemispheres with its distinctive Belt of three stars.
Orion\'s Belt points to Sirius (the brightest star) in one direction and Aldebaran (in Taurus) in the other!
Ursa Major (the Great Bear) contains the Big Dipper asterism, one of the most recognized star patterns in the northern sky.
Five of the Big Dipper stars are physically related, moving through space together as the Ursa Major Moving Group!
Ursa Minor (the Little Bear) contains the Little Dipper and Polaris, the current North Star marking Earth\'s celestial north pole.
Due to precession, Polaris won\'t always be the North Star - in 14,000 years, Vega will take its place!
Cassiopeia is a distinctive W-shaped constellation in the northern sky, named after a vain queen in Greek mythology.
Tycho Brahe\'s supernova of 1572 appeared in Cassiopeia, helping to prove that the heavens could change!
Scorpius is a prominent zodiac constellation with a distinctive curved tail, dominated by the red supergiant Antares.
In mythology, Scorpius was placed in the sky opposite Orion so the hunter would never be stung again!
Leo the Lion is a zodiac constellation featuring Regulus at the heart of the lion and the distinctive Sickle asterism.
The Leonid meteor shower in November appears to radiate from Leo and can produce spectacular storms!
Gemini the Twins features the bright stars Castor and Pollux, representing the twin brothers from Greek mythology.
Despite being called twins, Castor is actually six stars and Pollux is an orange giant - they look nothing alike!
Taurus the Bull is a zodiac constellation containing the Pleiades and Hyades star clusters, and the bright star Aldebaran.
The Crab Nebula in Taurus is the remnant of a supernova witnessed and recorded by Chinese astronomers in 1054 AD!
Virgo is the second largest constellation and a zodiac sign, containing the Virgo Cluster of over 2,000 galaxies.
The Virgo Cluster is the heart of the Virgo Supercluster, which contains our own Milky Way galaxy!
Aquarius the Water Bearer is a zodiac constellation in a region of sky often called the Sea, surrounded by water-related constellations.
Aquarius contains the Helix Nebula, one of the closest planetary nebulae to Earth at only 700 light-years away!
Pisces the Fishes is a large zodiac constellation representing two fish tied together, marking the vernal equinox point.
The vernal equinox (first day of spring) currently lies in Pisces and has been slowly moving through it for 2,000 years!
Aries the Ram is a zodiac constellation that was once home to the vernal equinox, giving us the phrase \"First Point of Aries.\"
Though the vernal equinox moved to Pisces about 2,000 years ago, we still call it the First Point of Aries!
Cancer the Crab is the faintest zodiac constellation but contains the famous Beehive Cluster (M44) visible to the naked eye.
The Tropic of Cancer was named when the Sun was in Cancer at the summer solstice, though it\'s now in Taurus!
Capricornus the Sea-Goat is an ancient zodiac constellation depicting a mythical creature that\'s half goat, half fish.
Capricornus is one of the oldest recognized constellations, appearing in Babylonian star catalogs over 3,000 years ago!
Sagittarius the Archer points toward the center of our Milky Way galaxy, making it rich in nebulae and star clusters.
When you look at Sagittarius, you\'re looking toward Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at our galaxy\'s center!
Libra the Scales is the only zodiac constellation representing an inanimate object, once considered part of Scorpius.
Libra\'s main stars were once known as the Claws of the Scorpion before becoming the Scales of Justice!
Cygnus the Swan flies along the Milky Way, containing the Northern Cross asterism and the bright star Deneb.
Cygnus X-1 in this constellation was the first widely accepted black hole, identified in the early 1970s!
Lyra the Lyre is a small but prominent constellation containing Vega, the fifth brightest star in the night sky.
Vega was the North Star around 12,000 BC and will be again in about 12,000 years due to Earth\'s precession!
Aquila the Eagle is a constellation on the celestial equator, containing the bright star Altair at its center.
Altair in Aquila is one of the fastest rotating stars known, spinning so fast it bulges at its equator!
Pegasus the Winged Horse is a large constellation featuring the Great Square of Pegasus, a prominent autumn asterism.
51 Pegasi b, discovered in 1995 in this constellation, was the first exoplanet found orbiting a Sun-like star!
Andromeda the Princess contains the Andromeda Galaxy (M31), the nearest large spiral galaxy to our Milky Way.
The Andromeda Galaxy is approaching us at 110 km/s and will merge with the Milky Way in about 4.5 billion years!
Perseus the Hero is home to the famous variable star Algol and the Double Cluster, a stunning pair of open clusters.
Algol (the Demon Star) was considered evil in ancient times because it mysteriously dims every 2.87 days!
Centaurus the Centaur is a large southern constellation containing Alpha Centauri, the nearest star system to our Sun.
Proxima Centauri in Centaurus is only 4.24 light-years away, making it the closest star to our solar system!
Crux (the Southern Cross) is the smallest constellation but one of the most distinctive, used for navigation in the Southern Hemisphere.
Despite being the smallest constellation, Crux has more bright stars per unit area than any other constellation!
Canis Major (the Great Dog) follows Orion across the sky and contains Sirius, the brightest star visible from Earth.
Ancient Egyptians based their calendar on the heliacal rising of Sirius, which coincided with the Nile\'s annual flood!
Canis Minor (the Lesser Dog) is a small constellation notable for Procyon, the eighth brightest star in the sky.
Procyon means \"before the dog\" in Greek because it rises just before Sirius (the Dog Star) each night!
Cepheus the King is a northern constellation whose stars include Delta Cephei, the prototype for Cepheid variable stars.
Cepheid variables discovered by Henrietta Leavitt revolutionized astronomy by allowing us to measure cosmic distances!
Draco the Dragon is a long, winding constellation that circles around Ursa Minor in the far northern sky.
Thuban in Draco was the North Star when the Egyptian pyramids were built, 5,000 years ago!
Hercules is a large constellation representing the Greek hero, containing the great globular cluster M13.
Our solar system is moving toward a point in Hercules called the solar apex at about 20 km/s!
Ophiuchus the Serpent Bearer lies along the ecliptic but isn\'t a zodiac sign, divided by the serpent he holds.
The Sun spends more time in Ophiuchus than Scorpius, yet Ophiuchus isn\'t considered a zodiac sign!
Bootes the Herdsman is a constellation containing Arcturus, the fourth brightest star in the night sky.
Follow the arc of the Big Dipper\'s handle to \"arc to Arcturus\" - one of the most famous navigation tips!
Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown) is a small semicircular constellation representing Ariadne\'s crown from Greek mythology.
T Coronae Borealis is a recurrent nova that erupts roughly every 80 years - another eruption may happen soon!
Corvus the Crow is a small quadrilateral constellation south of Virgo, representing Apollo\'s sacred bird.
The four main stars of Corvus form a distinctive sail shape that\'s easy to spot in the spring sky!
Auriga the Charioteer is a northern constellation featuring Capella, the sixth brightest star, and several open clusters.
Epsilon Aurigae is one of the strangest stars known, dimming for two years every 27 years due to a mysterious dark disk!
Eridanus the River is the sixth largest constellation, winding from near Orion to the far southern sky.
Achernar at the end of Eridanus is the flattest star known, bulging 56% wider at its equator due to rapid rotation!
Lepus the Hare crouches beneath Orion\'s feet, a small but distinctive constellation with a rich mythology.
In mythology, Orion was said to love hunting hares, so one was placed beneath his feet in the sky!
Monoceros the Unicorn is a faint constellation in the winter Milky Way, rich in nebulae and star clusters.
The Rosette Nebula in Monoceros is a massive star-forming region resembling a celestial rose!
Hydra is the largest constellation in the sky, representing the water serpent from Greek mythology.
Hydra stretches over 100 degrees of sky - more than a quarter of the way around the entire celestial sphere!
Carina the Keel was part of the huge Argo Navis constellation, containing the brilliant star Canopus.
Eta Carinae in Carina is one of the most luminous stars known and may explode as a supernova in our lifetime!
Vela the Sails was once part of the great ship Argo Navis, located in a rich region of the Milky Way.
The Vela Pulsar is the brightest pulsar in the sky and the remnant of a supernova that exploded 11,000 years ago!
Puppis the Stern represents the rear deck of the ship Argo Navis, rich in open clusters along the Milky Way.
Puppis contains M47, an open cluster visible to the naked eye that was \"lost\" for over 200 years due to a cataloging error!
Cetus the Sea Monster is a large constellation containing Mira, the first variable star ever discovered.
Mira in Cetus varies from visible to invisible over 11 months and has a 13-light-year-long tail of gas!
Phoenix is a southern constellation representing the mythical bird that rises from its own ashes.
Phoenix was one of 12 constellations created by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century from uncharted southern stars!
Grus the Crane is a southern constellation introduced in the late 16th century by European navigators.
Grus was once known as Phoenicopterus (the Flamingo) before being changed to represent a crane!
Pavo the Peacock is a southern constellation containing the bright star Peacock and several interesting galaxies.
The star Peacock (Alpha Pavonis) is the second most luminous star within 200 light-years of our Sun!
Triangulum is a small northern constellation containing the Triangulum Galaxy (M33), the third largest in the Local Group.
The Triangulum Galaxy is the most distant object that can be seen with the naked eye under ideal conditions!
Delphinus the Dolphin is a small but distinctive constellation whose stars form the shape of a leaping dolphin.
Two of Delphinus\'s stars are named Sualocin and Rotanev - \"Nicolaus Venator\" spelled backwards, the astronomer who named them!
Sagitta the Arrow is the third smallest constellation, representing various mythological arrows from Greek legends.
Despite being tiny, Sagitta contains M71, a globular cluster that was mistaken for an open cluster for centuries!
